Award.AwardTitle: The Effects of Physical Forces on Bacteria Growth

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Bacteria are the most populous and variable form of life on Earth. Bacteria can cause disease in humans as well as in animals and plants important to the food supply and the environment. However, bacteria can also be beneficial (probiotics) and are used industrially in the production of pharmaceuticals. Controlling bacterial populations is necessary to prevent disease and for quality control in industrial settings. Antibiotics are used to kill bacteria, but the development of new antibiotics has not kept up with needs in medicine and industry. Most antibiotics kill bacteria by causing mechanical failure (rupture) of the cell wall leading to cell death. The research goal of this work is to determine how bacterial physiology changes in response to physical forces and to determine how well the bacterial cell wall resists physical forces. The educational objectives of the work are to lead a week-long workshop on the mechanical properties of biological materials targeted to high-school students from traditionally under-represented groups and contribute to other activities to broaden participation in science by members of under-represented groups within the institution and at the national level.

Two hypotheses have been presented to explain the location and migration of intracellular proteins involved in cell wall synthesis: a) intracellular proteins involved in cell wall synthesis are directed by local cell wall curvature; and b) that cell wall synthesis proteins are directed to locations of increased cell wall stress/strain. This work addresses this question using a microfluidics-based mechanical testing approach that can modify mechanical stress/strain without large changes in cell wall curvature. The approach is novel in that it makes it possible to observe intracellular proteins in live bacteria while mechanical loading is being applied and does not require conditions of altered bacterial physiology (altered osmolality, filamentous growth, etc.). The research goals of this work are to: 1) Determine the relationship between mechanical strain, regions of cell wall growth and subcellular movement of a protein associated with cell wall synthesis (the MreB protein); and 2) Determine the entire mechanical strain field in the bacterial cell wall while load is applied.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Controlling the growth of bacteria is necessary to prevent infections and control biotechnology and food production and is therefore critical to human health, agriculture and food production and the environment. In this project we studied the effects of physical forces on the growth of bacteria and their resistance to toxins.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT: In this project we sought to understand how physical forces cause the deformation of individual bacteria and how bacteria respond to the physical forces. The work involved experiments in which bacteria were deformed under a microscope and related to the motion of individual molecules within the bacteria . We found that biological processes that allow the bacteria to remove toxins from their bodies are interrupted by mechanical deformation. Hence, physical forces have the potential to enhance the effectiveness of antibiotics. Using advanced mechanical modeling we found that the response to physical forces depends on the type of mechanical deformation: shape changing deformations (primarily shear) interrupt toxin removal while volume changing deformations (stretching/inflating) had minimal effects. To our knowledge, our findings are the first to demonstrate that physical forces influence biological processes in bacteria at the level of individual molecules. Our findings suggest a broad influence of physical forces on bacterial biology and may be useful in the development of new antibiotic strategies and biotechnolgy applications.

BROADER IMPACTS: The project supported efforts to broaden participation in science and technology among U.S. individuals from under-represented groups through a week-long research and educational experience for high school students and through annual contributions to professional development programs at the Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers national meeting. The research team led the scientific component of the 2015 CATALYST program (5, 4 hour-long laboratory experiences) serving 41 high school students (predominately US students from racial/ethnic groups traditionally under-represented in STEM fields). At the completion of the week the percentage of students choosing "very high confidence" for their ability to excel in engineering increased from 5% (2 students) to 37% (15 students) and the percentage of students aspiring to pursue a Ph.D. increased by 50%. The programs with the Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers involved professional training undergraduates, graduate students and junior engineering faculty.
